complications.name: Bile Duct Injury
complications.protocol: Step 1: Immediately recognize injury through cholangiography. Step 2: Convert to open surgery if needed. Step 3: Control bleeding and assess extent of injury. Step 4: Consult hepatobiliary surgeon immediately. Step 5: Primary repair if partial injury, hepaticojejunostomy if complete transection. Step 6: Place drains and monitor postoperatively. Step 7: Start broad-spectrum antibiotics.

complications.name: Hemorrhage
complications.protocol: Step 1: Apply direct pressure to bleeding site. Step 2: Ensure adequate IV access and fluid resuscitation. Step 3: Identify bleeding source. Step 4: Use clips, sutures, or electrocautery for hemostasis. Step 5: Convert to open if laparoscopic control fails. Step 6: Monitor vital signs continuously. Step 7: Transfuse blood products as needed.

complications.name: Saddle Nose Deformity
complications.protocol: Step 1: Assess structural support deficiency (septal cartilage, bone). Step 2: Plan reconstruction using autologous grafts (rib, septal, ear cartilage) or alloplastic material. Step 3: Address overlying soft tissue envelope if severely scarred. Step 4: Perform a robust septal reconstruction for future support. Step 5: Monitor nasal airway post-surgery.

complications.name: Infection
complications.protocol: Step 1: Obtain cultures and start empiric antibiotics (often targeting staph/strep). Step 2: Assess for abscess formation; drain if necessary. Step 3: Consider removal of foreign body/implant (e.g., synthetic grafts) if infection persists. Step 4: Monitor systemic signs of infection and wound healing. Step 5: Tailor antibiotics to culture sensitivity.

complications.name: Vascular Thrombosis
complications.protocol: Step 1: Early recognition (clinical signs: color, turgor, capillary refill). Step 2: Administer immediate systemic anticoagulation (e.g., heparin bolus). Step 3: Prompt return to operating theatre for surgical exploration/revision of anastomosis. Step 4: Consider thrombectomy or thrombolysis. Step 5: Optimize hemodynamics and hematocrit. Step 6: Use leeches/topical agents when appropriate. Step 7: Plan salvage procedures if required.

complications.name: Infection
complications.protocol: Step 1: Obtain wound cultures and start empiric antibiotics. Step 2: Debride infected/necrotic tissue. Step 3: Remove or revise implants if involved. Step 4: Consider negative pressure therapy for wound management. Step 5: Tailor antibiotics to culture sensitivity. Step 6: Monitor wound healing and systemic signs. Step 7: Plan reconstruction after infection control.

complications.name: Hematoma/Seroma
complications.protocol: Step 1: Identify collection clinically and with ultrasound. Step 2: Aspirate small seromas under sterile conditions. Step 3: Evacuate hematoma in theatre and achieve hemostasis for large collections. Step 4: Place drains as necessary. Step 5: Apply compression and immobilization. Step 6: Monitor for infection. Step 7: Remove drains when output decreases appropriately.

complications.name: Endophthalmitis (Infection)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Promptly confirm diagnosis. Step 2: Perform urgent vitreous tap for cultures. Step 3: Administer immediate intravitreal antibiotics. Step 4: Monitor visual acuity and systemic signs. Step 5: Consider vitrectomy if initial treatment fails.

complications.name: Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Immediate fundal massage and uterotonics (e.g., oxytocin). Step 2: Identify and treat cause (Atony, Trauma, Tissue, Thrombin). Step 3: Ensure adequate IV access; start rapid fluid/blood product resuscitation. Step 4: Consider surgical control (uterine artery ligation, B-Lynch suture, or hysterectomy) if conservative measures fail.

complications.name: Chronic Post-Operative Pain (Inguinodynia)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Rule out other causes (infection, recurrence). Step 2: Initiate multimodal pain management (NSAIDs, nerve blocks, gabapentinoids). Step 3: Refer to pain specialist. Step 4: Consider neurectomy (surgical removal of involved nerve) if conservative therapy fails after 6-12 months.

complications.name: Intra-abdominal Abscess
complications.protocol: Step 1: Confirm diagnosis with CT scan. Step 2: Start broad-spectrum IV antibiotics. Step 3: Perform percutaneous drainage under radiological guidance if feasible. Step 4: If drainage fails or abscess is complex/multi-loculated, consider laparoscopic or open surgical exploration and washout.

complications.name: Periprosthetic Joint Infection (PJI)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Immediate recognition (fever, pain, wound discharge). Step 2: Obtain joint aspiration for culture and cell count. Step 3: Initiate Debridement, Antibiotics, and Implant Retention (DAIR) for acute cases. Step 4: For chronic PJI, perform a two-stage exchange arthroplasty (remove implant, place antibiotic spacer, later reimplant).

complications.name: Postoperative Atrial Fibrillation (POAF)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Monitor rhythm continuously. Step 2: Administer prophylactic beta-blockers or amiodarone pre- and post-op. Step 3: If sustained AF, initiate rate control (beta-blockers, CCBs) or rhythm control (amiodarone, cardioversion). Step 4: Start anticoagulation based on patient risk factors (e.g., CHADS2VASC score).

complications.name: Post-Tonsillectomy Hemorrhage
complications.protocol: Step 1: Assess severity (primary <24h; secondary >24h). Step 2: Maintain patent airway and ensure IV access. Step 3: Resuscitate with fluids/blood as needed. Step 4: Return to operating room (OR) for immediate cauterization or ligation of the bleeding vessel under general anesthesia.

complications.name: Ureteral Injury
complications.protocol: Step 1: Immediate recognition (e.g., urine output changes, leakage, intraoperative inspection). Step 2: Place ureteral stent if discovered intraoperatively and injury is minor. Step 3: Perform primary ureteral anastomosis over a stent for major transections. Step 4: If discovered post-op, perform percutaneous nephrostomy for temporary decompression and delayed repair.

complications.name: Urinary Incontinence (Post-Radical)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Initial management with pelvic floor muscle training (Kegels) and biofeedback. Step 2: Use absorbent pads/devices. Step 3: Trial anticholinergic or beta-3 agonist medications. Step 4: If severe/persistent after 1 year, consider surgical intervention (male sling or artificial urinary sphincter).

complications.name: Lymphedema
complications.protocol: Step 1: Prevention through meticulous lymph node dissection and post-op care. Step 2: Initiate Complex Decongestive Therapy (CDT): manual drainage, compression garments, exercise, and skin care. Step 3: Patient education on lifetime risk management. Step 4: In refractory cases, consider microsurgical procedures (lymphovenous bypass or vascularized lymph node transfer).

complications.name: Hypocalcemia (due to Hypoparathyroidism)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Monitor serum calcium and PTH levels post-op. Step 2: Administer oral calcium and calcitriol (Vitamin D analogue) immediately if symptomatic or labs drop significantly. Step 3: Use IV calcium gluconate for severe, symptomatic hypocalcemia. Step 4: Titrate doses to maintain calcium levels in the normal range.

complications.name: Urosepsis
complications.protocol: Step 1: Recognize signs of systemic infection (fever, hypotension). Step 2: Aggressive fluid resuscitation. Step 3: Start broad-spectrum IV antibiotics immediately. Step 4: Ensure adequate urinary drainage (e.g., percutaneous nephrostomy tube or stent) to decompress the system.

complications.name: Non-union/Malunion
complications.protocol: Step 1: Confirm diagnosis with serial X-rays/CT scans showing lack of healing or deformity. Step 2: For non-union, perform revision surgery with aggressive debridement of fibrous tissue, bone grafting (autograft/allograft), and stable fixation (plate/nail). Step 3: For malunion, perform corrective osteotomy and fixation.

complications.name: Hip Dislocation (Post-op)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Immediate recognition (limb shortening, rotation, inability to move). Step 2: Perform closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia. Step 3: Confirm stable reduction and rule out fracture with X-ray. Step 4: Post-reduction, place in an abduction brace and restrict motion/weight-bearing for 6 weeks. Step 5: For recurrent dislocations, consider revision surgery.

complications.name: Stent Thrombosis
complications.protocol: Step 1: Immediate recognition (acute myocardial infarction). Step 2: Emergency return to cath lab. Step 3: Aspiration thrombectomy or balloon dilatation to restore flow. Step 4: Optimize antiplatelet and anticoagulant regimen (e.g., dual antiplatelet therapy) based on clinical status.

complications.name: Dural Tear/CSF Leak
complications.protocol: Step 1: Intraoperative recognition and immediate primary repair with fine suture, often supplemented with a patch (dural sealant, fat graft). Step 2: Post-op, enforce strict bed rest (Trendelenburg position) for several days. Step 3: Monitor for signs of persistent CSF leak or pseudomeningocele. Step 4: Consider a lumbar drain for prolonged leak.

complications.name: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Confirm diagnosis with Duplex ultrasound. Step 2: Initiate full-dose therapeutic anticoagulation (e.g., LMWH, DOACs). Step 3: Monitor for extension or signs of Pulmonary Embolism (PE). Step 4: Continue anticoagulation for at least 3-6 months.

complications.name: Perforation
complications.protocol: Step 1: Immediate recognition (clinical signs, free air on imaging, or endoscopic view). Step 2: Endoscopic clipping for small, stable perforations. Step 3: Surgical consultation; emergent laparoscopic or open repair for large or unstable perforations. Step 4: NPO, IV fluids, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

complications.name: Anal Stenosis
complications.protocol: Step 1: Prevention through mucosal preservation during surgery. Step 2: Initial management with stool softeners and local dilators. Step 3: For established stenosis, perform a surgical anoplasty (advancement flap) to widen the anal canal.

complications.name: Adrenal Insufficiency (Post-op)
complications.protocol: Step 1: Anticipate in patients with Cushing's or bilateral disease. Step 2: Start stress-dose steroid coverage (e.g., hydrocortisone) pre- and post-op. Step 3: Monitor electrolytes and blood pressure. Step 4: Taper steroids slowly over weeks/months, following hormone levels.

complications.name: Staple Line Leak/Fistula
complications.protocol: Step 1: Immediate recognition (tachycardia, fever, abdominal pain). Step 2: NPO, start broad-spectrum IV antibiotics. Step 3: Drain collection (percutaneous or surgically). Step 4: Endoscopic stenting or surgical repair may be required for definitive closure. Step 5: Nutritional support (TPN) is crucial.

complications.name: Septal Perforation
complications.protocol: Step 1: Monitor small perforations; patient education on humidification and lubrication. Step 2: Symptomatic management (whistling, crusting). Step 3: For larger or symptomatic perforations, plan surgical closure using mucosal flaps, often with interposition grafting (e.g., fascia, cartilage).
